thread.title: Woodmore's matchup with visiting Genoa more than soccer
thread.title_full: Woodmore's matchup with visiting Genoa more than soccer

title: Woodmore's matchup with visiting Genoa more than soccer
text:
Woodmore's matchup with visiting Genoa more than soccer Matthew Horn , Reporter 9:37 p.m. EDT October 8, 2015 Maddy Hines, right, scored twice and freshman Nora LaMunyon once in Woodmore's shutout victory Thursday. (Photo: Staff photo) 80 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Woodmore’s girls soccer team had already clinched the Northern Buckeye Conference crown. 
Thursday’s 3-0 victory over visiting Genoa (6-6-2, 3-4-2) was about more than soccer. 
“We knew going into the game we won the league title, but (Thursday) wasn’t just for us,” Wildcats forward Courteney Buchanan said. “It was for the community and Carson and Kennedy.” 
Thursday’s game was a fundraiser, including raffles and gate proceeds to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. Elmore’s Carson and Kennedy Slates, who suffer from the disease, were on the field before the game. 
Woodmore wore purple and Genoa’s game shirts were white and purple. 
The girls from each team were each introduced along with a member of the local U-9 or U-10 youth travel Patriots. The younger girls, along with Carson and Kennedy, also participated in the pregame warmup. 
Maddy Hines redirected a corner kick from Lily Rothert for the second goal and Hines capped the scoring early in the second half Thursday. 
Woodmore (11-1-1, 9-0) has won two of the last three conference championships. It finished second by one point last season. 
“We came back strong after a devastating loss,” Hines said of a district final setback to Archbold last season. “It shows the depth on our team. The team’s worked well together the entire season.” 
Freshman Nora LaMunyon opened the scoring about 14 minutes into the game. 
“We played good balls to the outside,” said Woodmore’s Alex Moreno, who was in goal for the shutout. “We found opportunities and finished them.” 
Woodmore advanced the the district finals each of the last three seasons. Wins like Thursday’s, as well as groups like the U-10 Patroits have Wildcats coach Jason Allen excited about both the present and future. 
“As a family, we hold each other accountable,” he said. “The talent just keeps coming.” 
mhorn@gannett.com
